to change the way that an organization, company, or product is seen by the public: Businesses may decide to rebrand for several reasons. We'll show you how to rebrand your organization in ten easy stages.
More examplesFewer examplesHer next step is to rebrand the product and reach a larger customer base.He was a brilliant political strategist who instinctively understood the need to rebrand the party.The city has cleaned up its sooty skies and rivers and now wants to rebrand itself as a happening place for culture.

  specialized the act of changing the way that an organization, company, or product is seen by the public: In June, the group launched a rebrand of its 1,021 stores. Often a rebrand is the result of poor branding in the first place.
More examplesFewer examplesDespite the rebrand, you wouldn't have to look too far to find the bigotry that motivates the party. The rebrand will improve global awareness and eliminate confusion in the market.the fanfare surrounding a multimillion-pound rebrand of the company

if a company rebrands itself or a product or service that it provides, it creates a new name or image for it, often to try to change the way that people think about it: The group intends to rebrand all its stores in three months.rebrand sth as sth Forte rebranded its Grand Hotels as Meridiens.rebrand as sth The station rebranded as Talksport at the start of the year. rebrand noun [ C ]
An attempted rebrand nine years ago was a disaster. rebranding noun [ U ]
The rebranding is a vital part of attempts to change the company culture.
